values.title: Allow GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH to point to a model directory

content.raw:
Currently, each element of `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` must be a directory that contains one or more models, each in its own subdirectory.  In some cases, it's convenient to point Gazebo directly at a directory that is a model, rather than pointing to it parent.

The need to point to the parent can have undesirable consequences, such as [drcsim issue #383](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/383/gazebo-looking-for-modelconfig-in-roslisp), where we put `<install_prefix>/share` in `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`, making Gazebo look in a bunch of unrelated directories for models.

Proposed logic, modeled from rospack:  for each element of `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`, first look for `model.config` in that directory.  If it's found, you have a model.  If it's not found, fall back on recursion as is done now.
content.html:
Currently, each element of GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH must be a directory that contains one or more models, each in its own subdirectory. In some cases, it's convenient to point Gazebo directly at a directory that is a model, rather than pointing to it parent.

The need to point to the parent can have undesirable consequences, such as drcsim issue #383, where we put <install_prefix>/share in GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH, making Gazebo look in a bunch of unrelated directories for models.

Proposed logic, modeled from rospack: for each element of GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH, first look for model.config in that directory. If it's found, you have a model. If it's not found, fall back on recursion as is done now.

values.title: cppcheck is not run for header files

content.raw: Currently our code check script only runs cppcheck for files with extension `.cc`, but we have a number of inline and template function implementations given in header files (mostly `.hh`). These files should be checked as well.
content.html: Currently our code check script only runs cppcheck for files with extension .cc, but we have a number of inline and template function implementations given in header files (mostly .hh). These files should be checked as well.

values.title: Resize tool does not change inertial properties

content.raw:
The resize tool changes the size of collision and visual objects, but it does not change the inertial properties of the link. If "View Center of Mass / Inertia" is enabled for a resized object, however, the inertia box is scaled along with the other visuals. This is misleading.

To be consistent, gazebo should either:

1. Scale the inertial values as the object is resized. OR

2. Visualize the correct inertia when the object is resized.
content.html:
The resize tool changes the size of collision and visual objects, but it does not change the inertial properties of the link. If "View Center of Mass / Inertia" is enabled for a resized object, however, the inertia box is scaled along with the other visuals. This is misleading.

To be consistent, gazebo should either:

  1. Scale the inertial values as the object is resized. OR

  2. Visualize the correct inertia when the object is resized.

values.title: DART does not detect closed loop automatically

content.raw:
Migrated from https://bitbucket.org/jlee02/gazebo_dart/issue/1/dart-does-not-detect-closed-loop

DART supports closed loop structure as an constraint which is solved by `ContactDynamics`. The closed loop constraint is not set automatically so the dart physics layer should add the constraint. This functionality is not implemted yet.

All pr2 tests are affected by this.

values.title: Build problems on saucy

content.raw:
There are some dependency issues when building gazebo from source on saucy. There are [saucy debs for sdformat that depend on boost 1.53](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat-release/src/d972e1242c786a8a17d015d60fede5370b132e66/saucy/debian/control?at=default#cl-21), which is the [saucy version of boost](http://packages.ubuntu.com/saucy/libboost-all-dev).

There seems to be an issue with the saucy package of ogre, however, which [depends on boost 1.49](http://packages.ubuntu.com/saucy/libogre-1.7.4).

values.title: Provide SetEffortLimit in Joint

content.html:
I'm working on programmatically setting the effort limit, for example to limit based on a curve. It would be nice to have physics::joint::SetEffortLimit(int _index, double value) implemented in a future version of Gazebo.

Currently, I use the following hack that makes me cry on the inside

class EffortSettableJoint : public physics::Joint
    {
    public:
        void SetEffortLimit(int _index, double value)
        {
            if (_index >= 0 && static_cast<unsigned int>(_index) < this->GetAngleCount())
            {
                this->effortLimit[_index] = value;
            }
        }
    };

(boost::static_pointer_cast<EffortSettableJoint>(joint))->SetEffortLimit(0, jointInitial.maximumforce());

values.title: gazebo_2.1 ABI broken by pull request #785

content.raw:
ABI compatibility of the gazebo 2.1 branch was broken by pull request #785 with the changes to World.hh

The method [ClearModels](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/1f637341bd9a974e660af684f22e7ecc134513f2/gazebo/physics/World.hh?at=gazebo_2.1#cl-460) can be moved to the end of the class definition to preserve ABI, but the addition of [private bool clearModels](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/1f637341bd9a974e660af684f22e7ecc134513f2/gazebo/physics/World.hh?at=gazebo_2.1#cl-703) would break it. I guess this is a reason to move towards PIMPL.
content.html:
ABI compatibility of the gazebo 2.1 branch was broken by pull request #785 with the changes to World.hh

The method ClearModels can be moved to the end of the class definition to preserve ABI, but the addition of private bool clearModels would break it. I guess this is a reason to move towards PIMPL.

values.title: Gtest version is unclear

content.raw:
We have a copy of gtest in this repo, but it is unclear which version it is. Through manual comparison with gtest tarballs, I have determined that it is version 1.6.0, with a single change:
~~~
diff -cr gtest-1.6.0/include/gtest/gtest-typed-test.h /home/scpeters/osrf/sdformat/test/gtest/include/gtest/gtest-typed-test.h
*** gtest-1.6.0/include/gtest/gtest-typed-test.h
--- gazebo/test/gtest/include/gtest/gtest-typed-test.h-0700
***************
*** 31,36 ****
--- 31,37 ----
  
  #ifndef GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_GTEST_TYPED_TEST_H_
  #define GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_GTEST_TYPED_TEST_H_
+ #pragma GCC system_header
  
  // This header implements typed tests and type-parameterized tests.
  
~~~
I propose adding the corresponding gtest CHANGES file to our copy of gtest.

This is motivated by gtest 1.6.0 having some issues on the latest version of osx.
content.html:
We have a copy of gtest in this repo, but it is unclear which version it is. Through manual comparison with gtest tarballs, I have determined that it is version 1.6.0, with a single change:

values.title: math: Quaternion::GetLog return type is confusing

content.raw:
Is there a reason why `Quaternion::GetLog` returns the exponential coordinates as a `Quaternion` instead of a `Vector3`? Really a such a function should return the skew-symmetric matrix corresponding to an element of so(3), but returning the angular velocity vector isn't too crazy of a thing to do. The current API could be confusing and lead to errors.

#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a676255484971eb823e037492a76fff1cfb66436/gazebo/math/Quaternion.cc?at=default#cl-97
content.html:

values.title: Consider using Eigen to improve math::Matrix classes

content.raw:
Currently, `math::Quaternions` can be converted to both `math::Matrix3` (element of SO(3)) as well as `math::Matrix4` (element of SE(3)), but the `math::Matrix3` class is missing several useful operations like matrix inversion and conversion back into a rotation. 

Are there any plans to clean up the math component?
content.html:
Currently, math::Quaternions can be converted to both math::Matrix3 (element of SO(3)) as well as math::Matrix4 (element of SE(3)), but the math::Matrix3 class is missing several useful operations like matrix inversion and conversion back into a rotation.

Are there any plans to clean up the math component?

values.title: Add configuration option to disable the sky in Gazebo

content.raw:
Currently, the only way to disable the sky (which causes problems on some machines http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/4703/how-to-disable-skyx/?answer=4880#post-id-4880) is to disable it in the source code and re-compile gazebo. Could this be made into an option that can be specified in the SDF? 

I'd do it, but the path between SDF `.world` configuration file and `Scene::SetSky` is complicated to figure out without being familiar with the codebase. 

Not that this does not require #693 because it would be configured before a world is created.

Additionally, this is important for doing free-flying space simulations where machine vision is involved and we want a dark black environment. For now, disabling the sky is good enough for this.
content.html:
Currently, the only way to disable the sky (which causes problems on some machines http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/4703/how-to-disable-skyx/?answer=4880#post-id-4880) is to disable it in the source code and re-compile gazebo. Could this be made into an option that can be specified in the SDF?

I'd do it, but the path between SDF .world configuration file and Scene::SetSky is complicated to figure out without being familiar with the codebase.

Not that this does not require #693 because it would be configured before a world is created.

Additionally, this is important for doing free-flying space simulations where machine vision is involved and we want a dark black environment. For now, disabling the sky is good enough for this.

I propose to improve the visualization by drawing the real ray sensors with a slightly darker color line. Something like this but probably with a thinner line.

I propose to improve the visualization by drawing the real ray sensors with a slightly darker color line. Something like this but probably with a thinner line.

values.title: JointController::Reset() should reset PIDs

content.raw:
When switching control mode (for example switching from position control to velocity control or torque control, and then back), the JoinController should be reset.
If during reset the PIDs don't get resetted as well, the iErr term is not reset, so that it might cause undesired behavior when switching control mode.
content.html: When switching control mode (for example switching from position control to velocity control or torque control, and then back), the JoinController should be reset. If during reset the PIDs don't get resetted as well, the iErr term is not reset, so that it might cause undesired behavior when switching control mode.

values.title: Write tutorial on adding simple hands

content.raw: DRC teams would like a tutorial on adding a simple 1-DOF or even 0-DOF (e.g., hook) hand to a robot.  I imagine that most of the content would be generic gazebo stuff, though some bits might be drcsim-specific, in that they'll want to know how to attach their hands to a simulated Atlas.
content.html: DRC teams would like a tutorial on adding a simple 1-DOF or even 0-DOF (e.g., hook) hand to a robot. I imagine that most of the content would be generic gazebo stuff, though some bits might be drcsim-specific, in that they'll want to know how to attach their hands to a simulated Atlas.

values.title: Crash while X11 forwarding over ssh

content.raw:
Initially posted by @dljsjr on [stackexchange.com](http://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/76005/x11-forwarding-an-opengl-application-from-a-machine-running-an-nvidia-card-to-a)

I'm interested in forwarding an X11 session over SSH, in order to launch a remote process that utilizes OpenGL (specifically, gazebo for anyone familiar.)

The problem that I seem to be running into is that gazebo crashes due to a mismatch in the graphics cards; it can't find "NV-GLX" extensions. The exact error output:

~~~
Xlib:  extension "NV-GLX" missing on display "localhost:10.0".
Xlib:  extension "NV-GLX" missing on display "localhost:10.0".
X Error of failed request:  GLXUnsupportedPrivateRequest
  Major opcode of failed request:  149 (GLX)
  Minor opcode of failed request:  16 (X_GLXVendorPrivate)
  Serial number of failed request:  24
  Current serial number in output stream:  25
~~~
The remote machine is running with an NVIDIA card, and my local machine is using an AMD card.

I've tested X11 forwarding of gazebo between two machines with NVIDIA cards. It works just fine.

As near as I can tell, it seems that one of three things are happening:

1. I'm doing something wrong,
2. What I want to do is impossible,
3. Gazebo doesn't build in an agnostic manner with branching codepaths for different hardware; whatever your system looks like when it builds is what you get.

I'm really hoping it's (1), and I'm really hoping someone here can help me out. If it makes any difference, the remote machine is running Ubuntu and my local machine is a Mac running 10.8.2; I already know that I have x11 forwarding set up properly for normal use as I can get things like xclock to open up in XQuartz just fine. The solution (if it exists) would also preferably work for other OS's including Windows over WinSCP.
content.html:
Initially posted by @dljsjr on stackexchange.com

I'm interested in forwarding an X11 session over SSH, in order to launch a remote process that utilizes OpenGL (specifically, gazebo for anyone familiar.)

The problem that I seem to be running into is that gazebo crashes due to a mismatch in the graphics cards; it can't find "NV-GLX" extensions. The exact error output:

Xlib:  extension "NV-GLX" missing on display "localhost:10.0".
Xlib:  extension "NV-GLX" missing on display "localhost:10.0".
X Error of failed request:  GLXUnsupportedPrivateRequest
  Major opcode of failed request:  149 (GLX)
  Minor opcode of failed request:  16 (X_GLXVendorPrivate)
  Serial number of failed request:  24
  Current serial number in output stream:  25

The remote machine is running with an NVIDIA card, and my local machine is using an AMD card.

I've tested X11 forwarding of gazebo between two machines with NVIDIA cards. It works just fine.

As near as I can tell, it seems that one of three things are happening:

  1. I'm doing something wrong,
  2. What I want to do is impossible,
  3. Gazebo doesn't build in an agnostic manner with branching codepaths for different hardware; whatever your system looks like when it builds is what you get.

I'm really hoping it's (1), and I'm really hoping someone here can help me out. If it makes any difference, the remote machine is running Ubuntu and my local machine is a Mac running 10.8.2; I already know that I have x11 forwarding set up properly for normal use as I can get things like xclock to open up in XQuartz just fine. The solution (if it exists) would also preferably work for other OS's including Windows over WinSCP.

values.title: Force Torque sensor (ForceTorqueSensor.cc) does not take into account sensor pose

content.raw: Force readings from the force torque sensor should be expressed wrt the sensor pose, instead of the child link pose.
content.html: Force readings from the force torque sensor should be expressed wrt the sensor pose, instead of the child link pose.

values.title: Respect user camera position using heightmaps

content.raw: Pull request #812 does not respect the <gui><camera><pose> tag from the world file. In any case the camera is set above the heightmap surface. We should set a flag in case the user uses <gui><camera><pose> and avoid the modification of the camera position in rendering::Heightmap.cc.
content.html: Pull request #812 does not respect the <gui><camera><pose> tag from the world file. In any case the camera is set above the heightmap surface. We should set a flag in case the user uses <gui><camera><pose> and avoid the modification of the camera position in rendering::Heightmap.cc.

values.title: Require sdformat 1.4.10 on default branch

content.raw: Once sdformat 1.4.10 is released, make the default branch require it.
content.html: Once sdformat 1.4.10 is released, make the default branch require it.

values.title: Joint::childLink not loaded correctly

content.raw:
Currently [Joint::LoadImpl](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/7c5787779908c1f00f4aba331656b001adaafe7c/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc?at=default#cl-193) has an error in its logic such that if `parentLink` is not `NULL`, `childLink` is not assigned.  This is done in error, the code should look like below:

~~~
hg diff gazebo/physics/Joint.cc 
diff -r 48b72097040b gazebo/physics/Joint.cc
--- a/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc	Thu Nov 07 10:51:37 2013 -0800
+++ b/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc	Thu Nov 07 12:05:44 2013 -0800
@@ -159,9 +159,11 @@
 
   if (this->parentLink)
     this->parentLink->AddChildJoint(boost::static_pointer_cast<Joint>(myBase));
-  else if (this->childLink)
+
+  if (this->childLink)
     this->childLink->AddParentJoint(boost::static_pointer_cast<Joint>(myBase));
-  else
+
+  if (!this->parentLink && !this->childLink)
     gzthrow("both parent and child link do no exist");
 
   // setting anchor relative to gazebo child link frame position
~~~
content.html:
Currently Joint::LoadImpl has an error in its logic such that if parentLink is not NULL, childLink is not assigned. This is done in error, the code should look like below:

hg diff gazebo/physics/Joint.cc 
diff -r 48b72097040b gazebo/physics/Joint.cc
--- a/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc   Thu Nov 07 10:51:37 2013 -0800
+++ b/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc   Thu Nov 07 12:05:44 2013 -0800
@@ -159,9 +159,11 @@

   if (this->parentLink)
     this->parentLink->AddChildJoint(boost::static_pointer_cast<Joint>(myBase));
-  else if (this->childLink)
+
+  if (this->childLink)
     this->childLink->AddParentJoint(boost::static_pointer_cast<Joint>(myBase));
-  else
+
+  if (!this->parentLink && !this->childLink)
     gzthrow("both parent and child link do no exist");

   // setting anchor relative to gazebo child link frame position

values.title: Joint::GetAnchor documentation needs improvement

content.raw: Documentation does not state reference location of the returned anchor point.  Currently it is actually in global frame, maybe more appropriate name for this function is `Joint::GetWorldAnchorPos`.
content.html: Documentation does not state reference location of the returned anchor point. Currently it is actually in global frame, maybe more appropriate name for this function is Joint::GetWorldAnchorPos.

values.title: gpu ray sensor vertical ranges

content.raw:
I have working code in the `gpu_vertical` branch but currently integration tests don't pass as the range readings seem to get less accurate as it approaches min/max vertical angles.

The problem is likely to be the maths in the initial gpu camera setup in `GpuRaySensor::Init()` or the depth image texture mapping code in `GpuLaser::CreateMesh`
content.html:
I have working code in the gpu_vertical branch but currently integration tests don't pass as the range readings seem to get less accurate as it approaches min/max vertical angles.

The problem is likely to be the maths in the initial gpu camera setup in GpuRaySensor::Init() or the depth image texture mapping code in GpuLaser::CreateMesh

values.title: Build fails with libc++ (Mac OSX 10.9 Mavericks)

content.raw:
Gazebo does not compile on the latest release of Mac OSX (10.9 Mavericks), which uses libc++ by default. There are compilation errors in gtest, related to tr1 headers. A fix for the gtest errors is to use gtest 1.7.0, as was done in [sdformat pull request 68](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/68/update-gtest-to-170-to-fix-osx-109-build).

I have done this in bebcb62 and am currently testing.
content.html:
Gazebo does not compile on the latest release of Mac OSX (10.9 Mavericks), which uses libc++ by default. There are compilation errors in gtest, related to tr1 headers. A fix for the gtest errors is to use gtest 1.7.0, as was done in sdformat pull request 68.

I have done this in bebcb62 and am currently testing.

content.raw:
It's been happening occasionally on Jenkins.

* 2.1 branch quantal gpu [build 9](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-gazebo_2.1-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/9/testReport/?)

* default gazebo/sdformat [build 15](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-sdformat-default-devel-quantal-amd64/15/testReport/?)

* default branch quantal gpu [build 346](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/346/testReport/?) and [build 348](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/348/testReport/?)

It's easiest to see the pattern in this last bullet point by comparing the console output from build 347 (pass) with the failures in 346 and 348.

values.title: gzclient can hang on Ctrl-C

content.raw:
(Follow-on to #441).

In testing while preparing pull request #829 and pull request #831, I saw `gzclient` hang a couple of times when shutdown soon (but not immediately) after start.  It's tricky to trigger, and I can't do it reliably.  It looks like the hang is due to the model database update thread not exiting.
content.html:
(Follow-on to #441).

In testing while preparing pull request #829 and pull request #831, I saw gzclient hang a couple of times when shutdown soon (but not immediately) after start. It's tricky to trigger, and I can't do it reliably. It looks like the hang is due to the model database update thread not exiting.

values.title: Laser Visual segmentation fault

content.raw:
In the LaserVisual constructor of branch 1.9, the OnScan callback is registered before the first point is added to rayFan. When the computers slows down (in big simulations) this leads to a segmentation fault in the OnScan callback (the rayFan->SetPoint(0, ...) line).

In version 2.0, this has been fixed in the rewrite of the component.

Bringing the subscription of the callback on the last line solved the problem for me.
content.html:
In the LaserVisual constructor of branch 1.9, the OnScan callback is registered before the first point is added to rayFan. When the computers slows down (in big simulations) this leads to a segmentation fault in the OnScan callback (the rayFan->SetPoint(0, ...) line).

In version 2.0, this has been fixed in the rewrite of the component.

Bringing the subscription of the callback on the last line solved the problem for me.

values.title: Streamline testing and maintenance of tutorials

content.raw:
There are a bunch of tutorials on gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials that require manual maintenance, including:

* Pasting code into wiki pages.
* Manually running the tutorials to verify functionality.

These two aspects could be streamlined:

* Don't paste code, but rather include code by reference using `<include pre src="http://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/raw/branch/path/to/file" />` (we just installed a wiki extension to enable this).
* Create regression tests for each tutorial to verify that it builds, and optionally test its functionality.

We should still go through the tutorials periodically, but these steps should make it easier to find problems.

A benefit of this would be that the tutorials are more likely to work.

A drawback is that modifying tutorials would require modifying code on bitbucket (either through a pull request to the main gazebo repo or by linking to a fork / branch).
content.html:
There are a bunch of tutorials on gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials that require manual maintenance, including:

  • Pasting code into wiki pages.
  • Manually running the tutorials to verify functionality.

These two aspects could be streamlined:

  • Don't paste code, but rather include code by reference using <include pre src="http://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/raw/branch/path/to/file" /> (we just installed a wiki extension to enable this).
  • Create regression tests for each tutorial to verify that it builds, and optionally test its functionality.

We should still go through the tutorials periodically, but these steps should make it easier to find problems.

A benefit of this would be that the tutorials are more likely to work.

A drawback is that modifying tutorials would require modifying code on bitbucket (either through a pull request to the main gazebo repo or by linking to a fork / branch).

values.title: Allow asymmetric joint effort limits

content.raw: Currently gazebo only supports symmetric joint effort limits (min_effort = -1 * max_effort). There may be robots with asymmetric joint effort limits (see [drcsim issue 361](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/361)), so this should be supported by gazebo.
content.html: Currently gazebo only supports symmetric joint effort limits (min_effort = -1 * max_effort). There may be robots with asymmetric joint effort limits (see drcsim issue 361), so this should be supported by gazebo.

values.title: Backport fix of #509 to gazebo_1.9

content.raw:
I experience troubles with vertical rays in the gazebo_1.9 branch. When replacing the horizontal tag by the vertical tag, the gazebo sensor doesn't load and hangs there until I kill the process.

A fix for vertical rays pull request #798 has been merged in default to fix #509.

I'm trying to simulate a Velodyne sensor with horizontal, vertical rays and the block laser plugin.

I'm trying to simulate a Velodyne sensor with horizontal, vertical rays and the block laser plugin.

values.title: Speed up gazebo test compilation

content.raw:
Currently several source files are recompiled for every test (Server.cc, Master.cc, gazebo.cc, and ServerFixture.cc). We could probably make a single static library from these files to speed up compilation and reduce the size of the build folder (the object files corresponding to these 4 source files take up about 350 MB in my build folder).

See the GZ_BUILD_TESTS_EXTRA_EXE_SRCS variable in [test/integration/CMakeLists.txt](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c5b1d48b8aeebf7e1ae801ef7542ec75312088d0/test/integration/CMakeLists.txt?at=default#cl-81) (and a few other places) and the gz_build_tests macro in [cmake/GazeboTestUtils.cmake](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c5b1d48b8aeebf7e1ae801ef7542ec75312088d0/cmake/GazeboTestUtils.cmake?at=default#cl-2)
content.html:
Currently several source files are recompiled for every test (Server.cc, Master.cc, gazebo.cc, and ServerFixture.cc). We could probably make a single static library from these files to speed up compilation and reduce the size of the build folder (the object files corresponding to these 4 source files take up about 350 MB in my build folder).

See the GZ_BUILD_TESTS_EXTRA_EXE_SRCS variable in test/integration/CMakeLists.txt (and a few other places) and the gz_build_tests macro in cmake/GazeboTestUtils.cmake

values.title: gazebo 1.9 does not set LD_LIBRARY_PATH for plugins

content.raw:
[gazebo_2.0 setups up `setup.sh.in` to update `LD_LIBARAY_PATH`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c5b1d48b8aeebf7e1ae801ef7542ec75312088d0/cmake/setup.sh.in?at=gazebo_2.0#cl-5), but [gazebo 1.9 does not](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/gazebo_1.9/cmake/setup.sh.in?at=gazebo_1.9).  We should add back
~~~
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=@CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX@/@LIB_INSTALL_DIR@/gazebo-@GAZEBO_VERSION@/plugins:${LD_LIBRARY_PATH}
~~~
and remove the [release overlay](#!/osrf/gazebo-release/src/default/precise/cmake/setup.sh.in?at=default).

But ultimately, we should push all the [pluigns](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/plugins/) install target to top level `${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/${LIB_INSTALL_DIR}/` (rather than [`${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/${LIB_INSTALL_DIR}/gazebo-${GAZEBO_VERSION}/plugins/`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/plugins/CMakeLists.txt?at=default#cl-40)) and rename the plugins to be prefixed by `Gazebo` or similar.
content.html:
gazebo_2.0 setups up setup.sh.in to update LD_LIBARAY_PATH, but gazebo 1.9 does not. We should add back

export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=@CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX@/@LIB_INSTALL_DIR@/gazebo-@GAZEBO_VERSION@/plugins:${LD_LIBRARY_PATH}

and remove the release overlay.

But ultimately, we should push all the pluigns install target to top level ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/${LIB_INSTALL_DIR}/ (rather than ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/${LIB_INSTALL_DIR}/gazebo-${GAZEBO_VERSION}/plugins/) and rename the plugins to be prefixed by Gazebo or similar.

values.title: Allow Multiple ContactSensor per collision geometry

content.raw:
Currently, only one `ContactSensor` per allowed for a collision geometry as the [`ContactManager::customContactPublishers`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c5b1d48b8aeebf7e1ae801ef7542ec75312088d0/gazebo/physics/ContactManager.cc?at=default#cl-268) are id'd by [collision geometry's entity name](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c5b1d48b8aeebf7e1ae801ef7542ec75312088d0/gazebo/sensors/ContactSensor.cc?at=default#cl-115).

Instead, do something like
~~~
    std::string topic = mgr->CreateFilter(entityName+"::"+sensorName, this->collisions);
~~~
to change this behavior.

This issue was motivated by [this test world with 2 contact sensors on one collision body](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/gazebo_plugins_test_world_update/gazebo_plugins/test/test_worlds/bumper_test.world).
content.html:
Currently, only one ContactSensor per allowed for a collision geometry as the ContactManager::customContactPublishers are id'd by collision geometry's entity name.

Instead, do something like

    std::string topic = mgr->CreateFilter(entityName+"::"+sensorName, this->collisions);

to change this behavior.

This issue was motivated by this test world with 2 contact sensors on one collision body.

values.title: Make physics engines pluggable

content.raw: Instead of hard-coding the available physics engines at build time, consider loading them dynamically using a plugin interface. This will enable optional physics engines to be installed as debian packages.
content.html: Instead of hard-coding the available physics engines at build time, consider loading them dynamically using a plugin interface. This will enable optional physics engines to be installed as debian packages.

values.title: Add support for bullet3 (GPU-accelerated physics)

content.raw: The [bullet3 repository](https://github.com/erwincoumans/bullet3) has support for GPU acceleration of the whole rigid body dynamics and collision checking pipeline. We should support this physics engine in Gazebo.
content.html: The bullet3 repository has support for GPU acceleration of the whole rigid body dynamics and collision checking pipeline. We should support this physics engine in Gazebo.

values.title: BulletHingeJoint::SetVelocity not working (commented out)

content.raw:
re-enabling the call to bullet in pull request #852 appears to fix this issue with bullet 2.82.


To test, compile gazebo_ros_pkgs with updated gazebo, start gazebo with bullet:

~~~
gazebo -s install/lib/libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so -e bullet
~~~

Replace plugin block in [pioneer2dx.model](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/b71974315dc51b717f8e49b4b8b55d234a8ece3e/pioneer2dx/model.sdf?at=default) with:
~~~
    <plugin filename="libDiffDrivePlugin.so" name="diff_drive">
      <left_joint>left_wheel_hinge</left_joint>
      <right_joint>right_wheel_hinge</right_joint>
      <torque>5</torque>
    </plugin>
~~~

Spawn (modified) pioneer2dx using the gzclient interface, then

~~~
rostopic pub /cmd_vel geometry_msgs/Twist '{ angular: { z: 1.0 } }'
~~~
content.html:
re-enabling the call to bullet in pull request #852 appears to fix this issue with bullet 2.82.

To test, compile gazebo_ros_pkgs with updated gazebo, start gazebo with bullet:

gazebo -s install/lib/libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so -e bullet

Replace plugin block in pioneer2dx.model with:

    <plugin filename="libDiffDrivePlugin.so" name="diff_drive">
      <left_joint>left_wheel_hinge</left_joint>
      <right_joint>right_wheel_hinge</right_joint>
      <torque>5</torque>
    </plugin>

Spawn (modified) pioneer2dx using the gzclient interface, then

rostopic pub /cmd_vel geometry_msgs/Twist '{ angular: { z: 1.0 } }'

values.title: physics::Base::childrenEnd causes failures with libc++

content.html:
Now that gazebo compiles on OSX 10.9, I've been testing it, and it isn't able to successfully load worlds. It appears to have problems with Base::childrenEnd, which seems to be a cached copy of Base::children.end(). This is referenced in numerous places in Entity.cc and Base.cc:

$ grep -rnI childrenEnd .
./gazebo/physics/Entity.cc:147:  for (iter = this->children.begin(); iter != this->childrenEnd; ++iter)
./gazebo/physics/Entity.cc:279:            iter != this->childrenEnd; ++iter)
./gazebo/physics/Entity.cc:313:      iter != this->childrenEnd; ++iter)
./gazebo/physics/Entity.cc:425:         iter != this->childrenEnd; ++iter)
./gazebo/physics/Entity.cc:441:         iter != this->childrenEnd; ++iter)
./gazebo/physics/Base.hh:309:      protected: Base_V::iterator childrenEnd;
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:63:       iter != this->childrenEnd; ++iter)
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:69:  this->childrenEnd = this->children.end();
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:110:  for (iter = this->children.begin(); iter != this->childrenEnd; ++iter)
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:115:  this->childrenEnd = this->children.end();
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:130:  for (iter = this->children.begin(); iter != this->childrenEnd; ++iter)
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:199:  this->childrenEnd = this->children.end();
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:206:  for (iter = this->children.begin(); iter != this->childrenEnd; ++iter)
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:215:  this->childrenEnd = this->children.end();
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:251:  for (iter = this->children.begin(); iter != this->childrenEnd; ++iter)
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:263:  this->childrenEnd = this->children.end();
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:270:  this->childrenEnd = this->children.end();
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:299:  Base_V::const_iterator iterEnd = this->childrenEnd;
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:346:  for (iter = this->children.begin(); iter != this->childrenEnd; ++iter)
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:356:  for (iter = this->children.begin(); iter != this->childrenEnd; ++iter)
./gazebo/physics/Base.cc:380:  for (iter = this->children.begin(); iter != this->childrenEnd; ++iter)

The problems arise in for loops with iter != this->childrenEnd. Switching to iter != this->children.end() appears to fix it. It seems like a bug to me. If it's an optimization, we should profile it and make sure it's worth the effort.

values.title: DART does not support Hinge2Joint
Redirecting the output of gztopic hz to a file does not work

content.raw:
The output is produced using printf and the output is not flushed when a file redirection is applied. Example:

```
#!c++

gztopic hz /gazebo/default/world_stats > log
```

The same problem happens when gztopic hz is combined with another command using a pipe.

Prefixing *unbuffer* to the command fixes the problem but I guess this is a Linux specific solution.

I propose to replace *printf* by *cout* to solve this issue.

See pull request #854.
content.html:
The output is produced using printf and the output is not flushed when a file redirection is applied. Example:

gztopic hz /gazebo/default/world_stats > log

The same problem happens when gztopic hz is combined with another command using a pipe.

Prefixing unbuffer to the command fixes the problem but I guess this is a Linux specific solution.

I propose to replace printf by cout to solve this issue.

See pull request #854.

values.title: Incorrect joint anchor position when child link pose is unset

content.raw:
There is an error when inserting a model like the following that has a single link connected to the world, specifically when a model pose is specified, but no link pose:
~~~
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.4">
  <model name="model">
    <pose>1 2 3 0 0 0</pose>
    <link name="child" />
    <joint name="joint" type="revolute">
      <parent>world</parent>
      <child>child</child>
      <axis>
        <xyz>1.0 0.0 0.0</xyz>
      </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>
~~~
In this case, since the pose offsets are zero for the child link and joint, the joint anchor location should be at `1, 2, 3, 0, 0, 0`. In practice, the joint anchor is being placed at the origin. I am writing a test to document this failure, and then I will fix it.
content.html:
There is an error when inserting a model like the following that has a single link connected to the world, specifically when a model pose is specified, but no link pose:

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.4">
  <model name="model">
    <pose>1 2 3 0 0 0</pose>
    <link name="child" />
    <joint name="joint" type="revolute">
      <parent>world</parent>
      <child>child</child>
      <axis>
        <xyz>1.0 0.0 0.0</xyz>
      </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>

In this case, since the pose offsets are zero for the child link and joint, the joint anchor location should be at 1, 2, 3, 0, 0, 0. In practice, the joint anchor is being placed at the origin. I am writing a test to document this failure, and then I will fix it.

values.title: Make Simbody cylinder and box (brick) mesh resolution a parameter

content.raw:
Currently hardcoded [cylinder to 1](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/577847c43d021f7edc838a30c0eafc99ea312571/gazebo/physics/simbody/SimbodyPhysics.cc?at=default#cl-1107) and [box to 2](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/577847c43d021f7edc838a30c0eafc99ea312571/gazebo/physics/simbody/SimbodyPhysics.cc?at=default#cl-1131).

For Atlas to walk stably, we need box mesh `resolution` parameter >= 6 (from trial and error testing).
content.html:
Currently hardcoded cylinder to 1 and box to 2.

For Atlas to walk stably, we need box mesh resolution parameter >= 6 (from trial and error testing).

values.title: crash when deleting multiple "default Camera Model" instances

content.raw:
You can recreate this error :

1. start gazebo
2. create two Camera instance  ( using "Insert" in the left column of gazebo gui )
3. delete the second Camera being created
4. gazebo terminated.

This will not happen if i delete the first Camera being created.

You can recreate this error :

  2. create two Camera instance ( using "Insert" in the left column of gazebo gui )

  4. gazebo terminated.

This will not happen if i delete the first Camera being created.

values.title: Ogre 1.9 change: codeToFile --> encodeToFile

content.raw:
It looks like "codeToFile" was changed to "encodeToFile" in OGRE 1.9, which causes the build to fail. I guess we will need ifdefs to choose between them based on the system OGRE version.

values.title: Build vs simbody failing with cmake problems

content.raw:
This is most likely an upstream problem with simbody, but just in case there's a way around it from gazebo:

I'm attempting to compile bitbucket gazebo with github simbody and failing to get gazebo to recognize my simbody source. (https://github.com/catskul/simbody.git)

It appears that it might be related to simbody's cmake scripts are written with some particular setup, but attempting to compile vs deb libsimbody-dev package fails as well.

Simbody_LIBRARIES are meant to be set once the find script has happened, but it fails because it cannot find the libraries

In the case of the deb package the problem is that the libraries are not in /usr/lib as expected but rather in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/


In the case of the from source build of simbody, it appears that their scripts make some bad assumptions about where the libs will be installed

originally I had tried and out of source build by creating a build directory and calling cmake back to the source root from there. When this did not work It appeared as if perhaps out of source simply wasn't supported, but when I called cmake from the source root itself, and it dumped all the artifacts right there, and also still failed in the same way it seemed clear there was a problem with the scripts.


When compiling gazebo vs source with the correct encantation:


```
#!
export SIMBODY_HOME=/home/user/sandbox/simbody/
cmake ../ -DSimbody_DIR=/home/user/sandbox/simbody/
```

I get:

```
#!
CMake Error: The following variables are used in this project, but they are set to NOTFOUND.
Please set them or make sure they are set and tested correctly in the CMake files:
Simbody_LIBRARIES (ADVANCED)
    linked by target "gazebo_physics_simbody" in directory /home/user/sandbox/gazebo/gazebo/physics/simbody
```

After some debugging it seems to be looking for libraries in 

```
#!
/home/user/sandbox/simbody/Simbody/lib
```

which doesn't exist as the build dumps all artifacts in whatever directory cmake was called from.
content.html:
This is most likely an upstream problem with simbody, but just in case there's a way around it from gazebo:

I'm attempting to compile bitbucket gazebo with github simbody and failing to get gazebo to recognize my simbody source. (https://github.com/catskul/simbody.git)

It appears that it might be related to simbody's cmake scripts are written with some particular setup, but attempting to compile vs deb libsimbody-dev package fails as well.

Simbody_LIBRARIES are meant to be set once the find script has happened, but it fails because it cannot find the libraries

In the case of the deb package the problem is that the libraries are not in /usr/lib as expected but rather in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/

In the case of the from source build of simbody, it appears that their scripts make some bad assumptions about where the libs will be installed

originally I had tried and out of source build by creating a build directory and calling cmake back to the source root from there. When this did not work It appeared as if perhaps out of source simply wasn't supported, but when I called cmake from the source root itself, and it dumped all the artifacts right there, and also still failed in the same way it seemed clear there was a problem with the scripts.

When compiling gazebo vs source with the correct encantation:

export SIMBODY_HOME=/home/user/sandbox/simbody/
cmake ../ -DSimbody_DIR=/home/user/sandbox/simbody/

I get:

CMake Error: The following variables are used in this project, but they are set to NOTFOUND.
Please set them or make sure they are set and tested correctly in the CMake files:
Simbody_LIBRARIES (ADVANCED)
    linked by target "gazebo_physics_simbody" in directory /home/user/sandbox/gazebo/gazebo/physics/simbody

After some debugging it seems to be looking for libraries in 

/home/user/sandbox/simbody/Simbody/lib

which doesn't exist as the build dumps all artifacts in whatever directory cmake was called from.

values.title: Coulomb friction parameters not handled properly in simbody

content.html:
There are a bunch of sliding boxes with difference coefficients of friction in test_friction.world. In ODE and bullet, two of the boxes remain still while the other boxes start to slide at different rates (according to their friction coefficient). In simbody, however, all the boxes slide at the same rate.

This could be a simple matter of parameters not being passed on correctly.

@sherm1 @tkuchida

values.title: a function to tell whether the Light is visible

content.raw:
I see a function for gazebo::rendering::Light::ShowVisual( bool ), that can toggle the visibility of a Light. 

It will be very be great if there is a function that can tell the visibility of Light.

Cause I don't want to turn off a light which is already off.

So i think it's reasonable to know the Light's visibility states.

Thanks

values.title: Universal Joint setup in ODE is inconsistent with manual demonstration

content.raw:
In [ODE manual](http://ode-wiki.org/wiki/index.php?title=Manual:_All&printable=yes#Universal), axis 1 is attached to body 1 (parent link) and axis 2 is attached to body 2 (child link).  From [experimenting with the joint](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/7d38f34f3d2704cab379b9bb0f91d86289b68f77/gazebo/physics/Joint_TEST.cc?at=simbody#cl-29), it appears the two axis associations are flipped.

Propose to flip them back during universal joint construction to make it consistent with the manual.
content.html:
In ODE manual, axis 1 is attached to body 1 (parent link) and axis 2 is attached to body 2 (child link). From experimenting with the joint, it appears the two axis associations are flipped.

Propose to flip them back during universal joint construction to make it consistent with the manual.

values.title: Bullet Universal Joint not working correctly
Add tooltip for Selection Mode keyboard shortcut

content.raw: The RTS (Rotate/Translate/Scale) controls have a hint in the tooltip that each mode can be accessed by pressing R, T, or S on the keyboard. The selection mode does not have this to indicate that Esc will return the user to this mode. We should add that into the tooltip.
content.html: The RTS (Rotate/Translate/Scale) controls have a hint in the tooltip that each mode can be accessed by pressing R, T, or S on the keyboard. The selection mode does not have this to indicate that Esc will return the user to this mode. We should add that into the tooltip.

In file included from /home/scpeters/ws/gazebo_ogre/devel_isolated/ogre/include/OGRE/Ogre.h:31:0,
                 from /home/scpeters/ws/gazebo_ogre/src/gazebo/gazebo/rendering/ogre_gazebo.h:22,

/home/scpeters/ws/gazebo_ogre/devel_isolated/ogre/include/OGRE/OgrePrerequisites.h:319:32: note: ‘Ogre::TexturePtr’ has a previous declaration here

I'm guessing there's an incompatibility between CEGUI 0.7.6 and OGRE 1.9.0, which wouldn't affect users with deb installs of OGRE and CEGUI, but could have problems with source installs.

Note that removing the libcegui debs causes drcsim and gazebo-current to be uninstalled as well.

values.title: Deprecation warnings when compiling with ogre 1.9

content.raw:
Discovered while reviewing pull request #883:

There's a lot of deprecation warnings when compiling gazebo against ogre 1.9:
~~~
warning: ‘virtual void Ogre::MovableObject::setUserAny(const Ogre::Any&)’ is deprecated
warning: ‘virtual void Ogre::MovableObject::setUserAny(const Ogre::Any&)’ is deprecated
~~~

[Full text of warnings here](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/8309238)

values.title: Create performance benchmark tests for the rendering module

content.raw:
- Sensors: Check if Image sensors (camera, multi-camera, depth) generate the correct Hz.

- General performance test, e.g. User Camera FPS
content.html:
• Sensors: Check if Image sensors (camera, multi-camera, depth) generate the correct Hz.

  • General performance test, e.g. User Camera FPS

values.title: Link Manipulation in GUI

content.raw:
Add ability to manipulate a link through GUI control.

See [demo video of link manipulation](http://youtu.be/EhUd4JbY-8Q) and [this demo video](http://youtu.be/LcWBFG7A_3I).
content.html:
Add ability to manipulate a link through GUI control.

See demo video of link manipulation and this demo video.

values.title: Heightmap textures failing to load

content.raw:
I'm struggling to get heightmap textures to work in gazebo. The problem I am having is illustrated in the attached image. Basically, the heightmap loads, but no textures are shown. I'm working from the stock heightmap.world packaged as part of gazebo-1.9.2. I've packaged the terrain into a model "location_terrain", which is defined below. All the resources are found correctly by the simulator and no error messages are returned.

```
#!xml

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<sdf version="1.4">
  <model name="location_terrain">
    <static>true</static>
    
    <link name="link">

      <collision name="collision">
        <geometry>
          <heightmap>
            <uri>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/terrain.png</uri>
            <size>129 129 10</size>
            <pos>0 0 0</pos>
          </heightmap>
        </geometry>
      </collision>

      <visual name="visual">
        <geometry>
          <heightmap>
            <texture>
              <diffuse>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/dirt_diffusespecular.png</diffuse>
              <normal>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/dirt_normal.png</normal>
              <size>1</size>
            </texture>
            <texture>
              <diffuse>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/grass_diffusespecular.png</diffuse>
              <normal>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/grass_normal.png</normal>
              <size>1</size>
            </texture>
            <texture>
              <diffuse>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/fungus_diffusespecular.png</diffuse>
              <normal>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/fungus_normal.png</normal>
              <size>1</size>
            </texture>
            <blend>
              <min_height>2</min_height>
              <fade_dist>5</fade_dist>
            </blend>
            <blend>
              <min_height>4</min_height>
              <fade_dist>5</fade_dist>
            </blend>
            <uri>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/terrain.png</uri>
            <size>129 129 10</size>
            <pos>0 0 0</pos>
            <use_terrain_paging>0</use_terrain_paging>
          </heightmap>
        </geometry>
      </visual>

    </link>
  </model>
</sdf>
```

Here is my world file...

```
#!xml
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<sdf version="1.4">
  <world name="example">

    <scene>
      <sky>
        <clouds>
          <speed>12</speed>
        </clouds>
      </sky>
    </scene>

	<include>
	  <uri>model://sun</uri>
	</include>

	<include>
	  <uri>model://location_terrain</uri>
	</include>

  </world>

</sdf>

```

I am working on a Lenovo Yoga 13" running Ubuntu 13.10. Here is the output of glxinfo, in case its a direct rending issue.

content.html:
I'm struggling to get heightmap textures to work in gazebo. The problem I am having is illustrated in the attached image. Basically, the heightmap loads, but no textures are shown. I'm working from the stock heightmap.world packaged as part of gazebo-1.9.2. I've packaged the terrain into a model "location_terrain", which is defined below. All the resources are found correctly by the simulator and no error messages are returned.

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<sdf version="1.4">
  <model name="location_terrain">
    <static>true</static>

    <link name="link">

      <collision name="collision">
        <geometry>
          <heightmap>
            <uri>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/terrain.png</uri>
            <size>129 129 10</size>
            <pos>0 0 0</pos>
          </heightmap>
        </geometry>
      </collision>

      <visual name="visual">
        <geometry>
          <heightmap>
            <texture>
              <diffuse>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/dirt_diffusespecular.png</diffuse>
              <normal>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/dirt_normal.png</normal>
              <size>1</size>
            </texture>
            <texture>
              <diffuse>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/grass_diffusespecular.png</diffuse>
              <normal>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/grass_normal.png</normal>
              <size>1</size>
            </texture>
            <texture>
              <diffuse>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/fungus_diffusespecular.png</diffuse>
              <normal>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/fungus_normal.png</normal>
              <size>1</size>
            </texture>
            <blend>
              <min_height>2</min_height>
              <fade_dist>5</fade_dist>
            </blend>
            <blend>
              <min_height>4</min_height>
              <fade_dist>5</fade_dist>
            </blend>
            <uri>model://location_terrain/materials/textures/terrain.png</uri>
            <size>129 129 10</size>
            <pos>0 0 0</pos>
            <use_terrain_paging>0</use_terrain_paging>
          </heightmap>
        </geometry>
      </visual>

    </link>
  </model>
</sdf>

Here is my world file...

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<sdf version="1.4">
  <world name="example">

    <scene>
      <sky>
        <clouds>
          <speed>12</speed>
        </clouds>
      </sky>
    </scene>

    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>

    <include>
      <uri>model://location_terrain</uri>
    </include>

  </world>

</sdf>

I am working on a Lenovo Yoga 13" running Ubuntu 13.10. Here is the output of glxinfo, in case its a direct rending issue.

values.title: Coulomb friction parameters not handled properly in dart

content.raw:
There are a bunch of sliding boxes with difference coefficients of friction in [test_friction.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/9410f80cf7a70accd8cde7617b2800872283849f/sdf/worlds/test_friction.world?at=default). In ODE and bullet, two of the boxes remain still while the other boxes start to slide at different rates (according to their friction coefficient). In dart, however, all the boxes slide at the same rate.
This could be a simple matter of parameters not being passed on correctly.

(Similar to #989 for simbody)

@jlee02 @karenliu
content.html:
There are a bunch of sliding boxes with difference coefficients of friction in test_friction.world. In ODE and bullet, two of the boxes remain still while the other boxes start to slide at different rates (according to their friction coefficient). In dart, however, all the boxes slide at the same rate. This could be a simple matter of parameters not being passed on correctly.

(Similar to #989 for simbody)

@jlee02 @karenliu
